data.title: Post-Grad Music Reviews
data.meta_description: Posts about alternative written by Andrew McNally
data.text:
Grade: A-

Key Tracks: â€œ4Ã†M,â€ â€œMy Name Is Darkâ€

Hey! Hi! Hello! Iâ€™m still alive and paying for this domain â€“ and although I havenâ€™t had time to maintain this blog in a few years, I want to try to start again! Iâ€™m sure my [REDACTED NUMBER] followers will be delighted ğŸ™‚

(Review originally published on thefilteredlens.com)

A lot has changed since the release of Grimesâ€™ last album, 2015â€™s untouchable â€œArt Angels.â€ The albumâ€™s mix of bouncy and eerie pop melodies rocketed the already-rising Grimes into a much bigger light, and placed near the top of seemingly every year-end list (overshadowed solely by â€œTo Pimp a Butterflyâ€). In that time sheâ€™s come as close to a household name as someone who makes eclectic dream-pop would, all the while testing some fans and hyping up others with her surprise romance with Tesla/Space-X epic bacon dudebro Elon Musk. My opinion of her has soured, deeply, but my opinion of her music hasnâ€™t. Itâ€™s difficult to weight the two against each other for her new album, but itâ€™s a stellar album nonetheless.

From a sheer musical standpoint, â€œMiss Anthropoceneâ€ is a big departure from the conventional structures of â€œArt Angels,â€ and is more aligned with her older work. Itâ€™s a smart attempt to try and re-couple with the section of fans that didnâ€™t approve of the last albumâ€™s conventionality. A majority of the songs across â€œAnthropoceneâ€ have a much more atmospheric tone, with sweeping synth and distant, largely indecipherable vocals and lyrics. At the same time, she ropes in some elements of nu-metal, much akin to the recent Poppy heel turn. The albumâ€™s only real bop is the excellent â€œ4Ã†M,â€ which punctures the format by adding some breakbeats.

Thematically, â€œAnthropoceneâ€ takes on a much darker tone than its predecessor (which wasnâ€™t exactly a glimmer of hope, itself). The album follows a goddess of climate change who, very literally, wants to watch the world burn. Various songs address various apocalypses (think King Gizzâ€™s â€œMurder of the Universeâ€) from climate change (â€œSo Heavy I Fell Through the Earthâ€) to opiate addiction (â€œDelete Foreverâ€). Itâ€™s a lofty ambition for someone whoâ€™s career was at a bit of a crossroads, and she pulls it off masterfully well. Some of the albumâ€™s slowest tracks, like â€œNew Godsâ€ and â€œBefore the Fever,â€ donâ€™t exactly demand immediate replays. But on the context of a full album, they highlight songs like the rapid â€œ4Ã†Mâ€ and the euphoric closer â€œIDORUâ€ remarkably.

If Grimes is attempting to reconnect with her older roots here â€“ and she may not be, but â€œAnthropoceneâ€ is similar to older releases like â€œHalfaxaâ€ â€“ then there is a contradictory elephant in the room. Grimes got her start in witch house, although she never felt fully encompassed in the genre. Witch house bands are inherently anti-technology, with some choosing unsearchable names like oOoOO and ///â–²â–²â–²\\\. â€œAnthropoceneâ€ isnâ€™t a witch house album, but the roots are still there, and the sentimentality is present. Early single â€œWe Appreciate Powerâ€ (left off the album but available on deluxe versions) is sung from the POV of an AI propaganda machine. Itâ€™s a powerful message (and a great song). But it is easily misconstrued because of the POV as being some kind of pro-techno-fascist nightmare, and itâ€™s telling that it isnâ€™t immediately apparent that Grimes meant otherwise. Her coupling with Elon Musk, our eraâ€™s most worryingly successful techno-fascist, deems a lot of the albumâ€™s genuine concerns either contradictory or irrelevant. Not to mention, her faux-edgy Tumblr aesthetics feel a lot sillier this time around, with song titles like â€œDelete Foreverâ€ and â€œMy Name is Darkâ€ and lyrics like (seriously) â€œSo we party when the sun goes low / Imminent annihilation sounds so dope.â€ I watched the film â€œSnowpiercerâ€ for the first time last night (inspired by â€œParasite,â€ not by this album) and knowing how Musk is developing super-transportation and accumulating ungodly personal wealth amidst a likely catastrophic climate crisis, it feltâ€¦.on the nose. This, uh, musk, is extremely difficult to shake off while listening to â€œAnthropocene.â€

That said, if you can look past that, or if youâ€™re a fan of Musk and this partnership, then this still an incredible record. Glorifying and horrifying, Grimes plays to all of her own strengths. The album is almost devoid of bangers like â€œKill V. Maim,â€ but as good as that song is, it never felt like Grimesâ€™s comfort zone. From the eerily quiet intro â€œSo Heavy I Fell Through the Earthâ€ to the sonic vaccuum of â€œMy Name is Darkâ€ to the unexpectedly sweet finale, â€œAnthropoceneâ€ is a well-rounded and satisfying that, like her previous albums, is bound to get better with each listen. There is a lot to pick apart, especially in the urgency of some of the lyrics. But even just as a sonic experience, it feels miles ahead of â€œArt Angelsâ€ in scope and ambition, even in the quiet moments. I wasnâ€™t sure what direction Grimes would take after â€œAngels,â€ but she really sticks the landing.

~By Andrew McNally

Grade: B

Key Tracks: â€œColorsâ€ â€œDreamsâ€

Beck is a literal cornucopia musician â€“ you never know what the next album is going to sound like. And while thereâ€™s plenty of other musicians that do the same, they rarely have such big hits as Beck, and rarely do it so alone. Letâ€™s take his 2005 album â€œGueroâ€ â€“ thereâ€™s 11 other credited musicians, but Beck is credited on 20 instruments, and two of those other musicians are credited with spoken word bits and another is credited on â€œadditional sounds.â€ This album was made with Greg Kurstin, who is credited on veery song along Beck, and almost no one else shows up. Beck has always straddled the line of total outcast â€“ often improvising lyrics in the studio and blending combinations folk, rock, rap, pop, and electronic genres on a whim â€“ and industry favorite, helping to define and cement alternative music more than almost any other artist. On â€œColors,â€ his thirteenth album, he again takes a hard left-turn, this time embracing the pop spotlight heâ€™s so often avoided.

This is Beckâ€™s first album since 2014â€™s â€œMorning Phase,â€ which won a shocking Album of the Year Grammy (an award so much in Beyonceâ€™s favor that Beckâ€™s speech was barely above surprised mumbling, and featured a tongue-in-cheek Kanye interruption). â€œMorning Phaseâ€ was a soft and blissful record, mistaken for somber. It was a direct follow-up to 2002â€™s entirely acoustic â€œSea Change,â€ with Beck marking the passage of time and the acceptance he has gained since the disastrous break-up that spawned that classic. But the albumâ€™s outlook is much brighter than the music seems. And it makes sense that while Beck was working on that record, he was also developing some of the tracks on this album, even though the albums couldnâ€™t sound more different. The tracks on â€œColorsâ€ are easily the poppiest thing heâ€™s ever done, at least on a full-album scale. This is a straight pop album, and while it isnâ€™t always effective, it is a lot of fun to hear Beck bounce back in an unexpected way.

â€œColorsâ€ might be the closest thing to a genre album that Beckâ€™s ever done. Even later albums like â€œThe Informationâ€ had diversity amongst tracks. This album has big pop beats throughout and, at times, Beckâ€™s return to the pseudo-rapping of his heyday. Radio pop is the one thing Beck really has left to conquer, so it makes sense that at this stage in his career he would attempt it. By this point, he has nothing left to lose and a solid legacy intact. The title track has a pan flute, â€œIâ€™m So Freeâ€ has rapping, â€œWowâ€ has both. And every track on this album is inherently catchy and dancefloor-ready. Even at his weirdest, Beck has always mastered catchiness, but here it isnâ€™t hidden behind slide guitar, or robotic noises, or sitar, or whatever else he had laying around.

The album isnâ€™t without downtime, however. Even though it clocks in at 39 minutes, thereâ€™s some fat on the albumâ€™s bones. Songs like â€œNo Distractionâ€ and â€œUp All Nightâ€ suffer from bland lyrics and the vague catchiness that plague the entire generation of indie music right now, most of whom are imitating Beck in some way. Although Beckâ€™s music hasnâ€™t always been perfect, heâ€™s never seemed like one who would become a victim of his own creation like he does on â€œColors.â€ Also, a weird disappointment of the album is that the whole piece is centered on the song â€œDreams,â€ a guitar odyssey with one of the most memorable bridge sections in any alternative song. But, the song was released a single over two years ago, and has already gone through the whole radio rise-and-fall process and drifted from many peopleâ€™s radars (not mine admittedly, I love the track). To center the album around this song seems like a cash-out, like Beck admitting that in the two years since he hasnâ€™t been able to craft up something as good.

Still, the album is a fun and accessible, if not forgettable listen. It stands along with â€œSea Changeâ€ and â€œMorning Phaseâ€ as the most directly cohesive listens in the Beck discography, therefore also making them the outliers. He successfully hides his years throughout â€œColors,â€ pulling off a batch of songs normally reserved for musicians who fell in love with â€œLoserâ€ in middle school. Itâ€™s another new side of Beck: party Beck. And while I hope party Beck doesnâ€™t stick around very long for fear of getting very tiresome, it is a welcome presence. It also makes me ravenous for whatever Beck will have up his sleeve for his next album. But for now, enjoy all the different shades of Beckâ€™s â€œColors.â€

-By Andrew McNally

Grade: A

Key Tracks: â€œPills,â€ â€œSugarboy,â€ â€œYoung Loverâ€

Annie Clark has big shoes to fill. Her last album, 2014â€™s â€œSt. Vincent,â€ was consistently ranked among the best albums of the year, a busy year. The album saw her rise from indie darling touring the festival circuit to playing the season finale of â€œSNLâ€ and winning a semi-surprise Best Alternative Album at the Grammyâ€™s (ironically, presumed winner Beck also released a new album this week). After all that, â€œSt. Vincentâ€ is my favorite album. Like, ever. All-time. Has been for three years. So â€œMASSEDUCTIONâ€ has high hurdles to clear and, to our baited breaths, it jumps over those hurdles in every way that Annie Clark can think of.

Donâ€™t let opening track â€œHang On Meâ€ and lead single â€œNew Yorkâ€ fool you â€“ this is a big album. At 13 tracks and 41 minutes, it packs a whole boxerâ€™s array of punches. Although the opening song is inexplicably lackluster, the album kicks into high gear with the guitar-heavy satire â€œPills.â€ The trackâ€™s fuzzy, chomping guitar sounds like an â€œActorâ€ lost cut. One of the albumâ€™s few disappointments is that this is really the only track where Clark lets loose on guitar, something she still does a little infrequently. But when the album that follows is as good as it is, itâ€™s hardly even missed.

Other standout tracks include â€œSugarboy,â€ with a super catchy and choppy beat thatâ€™s sure to rip through audiences in her live show. â€œHappy Birthday, Johnnyâ€ is a slight ballad with some unexpected country slide-guitar, stuck right in the middle of the album. â€œSaviorâ€ is a funky and sexy pop song, but one that includes industrial elements (although he doesnâ€™t have a songwriting credit, the album was co-produced by Jack Antonoff, who cowrote and produced a similar, excellent song on Lordeâ€™s album earlier this year). â€œFear The Futureâ€ hits super hard after the emotional but slight â€œNew York,â€ with a deafening sound and incredibly anxious lyrics. â€œYoung Lover,â€ the tenth track, seems like the beginning of the wind-down as, frankly, the songâ€™s first section is dull. But it transforms into a full-bloomed vocal track, the best of the album and one of the best in Clarkâ€™s discography. The albumâ€™s final song â€œSmoking Sectionâ€ is a satisfying conclusion, with Clark repeating â€œitâ€™s not the end.â€ The songâ€™s title and placement might be a reference to David Sedarisâ€™s classic essay â€œThe Smoking Sectionâ€ â€“ let us not forget that Clarkâ€™s debut contained references to â€œArrested Developmentâ€ and MAD Magazine.

â€œMASSEDUCTIONâ€ is not without fault, of course. There are rare moments of downtime, in tracks like â€œHang On Me,â€ â€œSlow Disco,â€ and, to a lesser extent, the title track. There is also a palpable lack of guitar wizardry. Although Clarkâ€™s guitar pops up throughout, the album generally lacks the riffs designed to pummel live audiences to their core. Itâ€™s a confounding stylistic choice for someone who is becoming known as one of the best live acts. Still, audiences havenâ€™t seen these songs performed yet, so whoâ€™s to say what Clark has planned (also, sheâ€™s just free to record whatever she wants, maybe sheâ€™s just tired of guitar).

Although not her best overall, this album stands as easily the most cohesive record in the St. Vincent discography. It has the fewest amount of skippable tracks (thereâ€™s only two that Iâ€™d even consider and Iâ€™ve *just* listened to it), it has everything from anxious noise about the future to industrial-funk to genuinely beautiful ballads to satire about the medical industry. Iâ€™ve written (in a few places, extensively, sorry) about the impact that Clarkâ€™s 2012 collaborative album with David Byrne, â€œLove This Giant,â€ seemed to have on her confidence as a performer. That newfound confidence shines throughout this entire record, front (back?) and foremost with that album cover. Clark has always been an interesting songwriter, but this album continues her trend of pushing listeners out of their comfort zone with the frequent genre changes and occasionally uncomfortable lyrics.

This album is a borderline-masterpiece, if not one outright. Although it lacks specifically-standout songs like all of her other albums (â€œRattlesnakeâ€ & â€œBirth In Reverse,â€ â€œCruelâ€ & â€œSurgeon,â€ â€œThe Neighborsâ€ & â€œMarrow,â€ â€œNow, Nowâ€ & â€œYour Lips Are Red), it works as a huge cohesive unit that really doesnâ€™t have much time to cut. Itâ€™s a challenging pop album, asking the listener to accept satire, sorrow and directly sexual lyrics amidst their catchy music. This album feels like all of the highs, lows and middles that Clark has been living since and possibly before her last album. This album was likely going to be the one that people really judged Clark on. Her last album is, for all intents and purposes, a breakthrough â€“ so the eye was on what she would do with the exposure. And if this album is what Clark can do under the pressure, then itâ€™s safe to say weâ€™re welcoming in a new legend.

-By Andrew McNally

Grade: A-

Key Tracks: â€œThe Sound of War,â€ â€œUndercoverâ€

Susanne SundfÃ¸r, more than most people in music, understands the concept of a human voice as an instrument. She also clearly understands that she possesses one of the most operatic and resounding singing voices around, which she uses on full display on her sixth album. Her previous two works, 2012â€™s â€œThe Silicone Veilâ€ and 2015â€™s â€œTen Love Songsâ€ used heavy doses of strings and synth to create rich, dichotomous harmonies that played equally off her beautiful and sometimes pained vocals. On this album, though, she lets her voice create part of the harmony rather than acting as the knife that splits those harmonies apart. The album is much, much softer, often consisting of just SundfÃ¸râ€™s vocals and acoustic guitar, with an occasional wind instrument.

Although the album does have some prominent features, many tracks are just SundfÃ¸r, accompanying herself on guitar or piano (often acoustic guitar). Acoustic guitar is an instrument that has felt intentionally left out of her music on prior albums, so the immediacy of it on â€œTroubleâ€ signals the shift in sound, as well as working as an ode to her natural talent.

As expected, the lyrics are often dark and planted in the concepts of personal issues, relationships and conflicts dying unresolved. More so on â€œTroubleâ€ than on past albums, itâ€™s easy to let SundfÃ¸râ€™s voice wash over as a separate instrument, to disregard the words for the emotion theyâ€™re reflecting. The albumâ€™s softer tone also brings out the true qualities in her vocals â€“ she doesnâ€™t have to overpower any instruments, sheâ€™s just belting because she feels the song requires. The only track where this doesnâ€™t necessarily apply is lead single â€œUndercover,â€ a track that has the instrumentation and vocals build together rather than separate, and where SundfÃ¸r sounds even bigger than she does elsewhere. Itâ€™s the albumâ€™s best example of a â€˜put your headphones on and get lost in itâ€™ type song, akin to â€œAccelerate.â€

In many respects, â€œSongs For People In Troubleâ€ is the polar opposite (and answer to) â€œTen Love Songsâ€ (a personal favorite album of mine). â€œTroubleâ€ only allows itself to go off the rails twice, on â€œThe Sound of Warâ€ and itâ€™s immediate follow-up, the title track. â€œWarâ€ starts as innocently as many of the albumâ€™s other tracks, gorgeous and soft, before giving way to a more drone finale. The title track cements the album at the halfway point, and itâ€™s first half is spoken-word poetry performed by Andres Roberts and avant-garde.

The album does twist its way into the final song (and second single), â€œMountaineers,â€ which has the only actual official feature, a bold duet with John Grant. Itâ€™s a song that is as inquisitive as it is engaging, and doesnâ€™t feature SundfÃ¸r until a ways in. But, in keeping with traditions of ending her albums on big, bold notes (check â€œYour Preludeâ€ and â€œInsects,â€ songs with enormous sound to them), the song feels like driftwood caught in the rest of the albumâ€™s waves. Even for the album, itâ€™s a complicated and risky song, one that pays off more with each listen.

â€œTroubleâ€ is standout, tempered pop, accentuated by touches of music that only occasionally become heavy touches. SundfÃ¸r again uses her voice as an instrument, dominating songs like â€œReincarnationâ€ while stepping aside for things like an extended flute solo in â€œNo One Believes in Love Anymore.â€ Although the sound is almost jarringly different from her more recent works, it recaptures the leveled sound of her earlier career without losing any of the ambition and emotional haunting of her more synth-based songs. â€œTroubleâ€ is quiet and daring, another ten song collection that leaves the listener cold, a little shaken but still asking for so much more.

Grade: B+

Key Tracks: â€œHead Like A Haunted House,â€ â€œThe Evil Has Landedâ€

Whenever Josh Homme is involved with a new project, itâ€™s always telling to look at who he has chosen to surround himself with. Although the bandâ€™s current line-up has stayed mostly intact since the â€œEra Vulgarisâ€ days of a decade ago, Hommeâ€™s albums have always reflected those around him. Heâ€™s worked with everyone from Dave Grohl to Iggy Pop to John Paul Jones to Lady Gaga to Elton John, and often reflects back on them. This album, though, has no features â€“ not even Mark Lanegan. It only takes one person out for a spin, but that person is Mark Ronson. Ronson met Homme while producing Gagaâ€™s â€œPerfect Illusion,â€ which Homme guests on. Ronson is known for his diverse collaborations, often wringing the best possible work out of acts like Bruno Mars, Mystikal and Amy Winehouse â€“ but a hard rock band like Queens of the Stone Age was still a bold choice to produce.

QOTSA really thrust themselves in a new direction on â€œVillains,â€ their seventh album. Their first six albums, though all different, set a template for the band that gets largely demolished here. Gone are the hard-rock crunches of â€œSick Sick Sickâ€ and the blunting tempo changes of â€œSong for the Dead.â€ Instead, we get (mostly) some danceable rock. Quite frankly, â€œVillainsâ€ sounds like the meeting point between Ronson and QOTSA that we were expecting. Opener â€œFeet Donâ€™t Fail Meâ€ really sets the tone, with an almost silent intro that leads to a midtempo, synth heavy beat thatâ€™s a far distance from â€œFeel Good Hit of the Summer.â€ The party hits its peak halfway through the album, on â€œHead Like a Haunted House,â€ a disco-y track with an almost circus bassline that gets so party that it becomes a little draining.

Regular olâ€™ grinding QOTSA still works their way into the album, too. â€œDomesticated Animalsâ€ is an exploration into what itâ€™s like to play the same three chords on repeat for over five minutes and, as far as QOTSA album tracks are considered, itâ€™s as successful as you might expect. The albumâ€™s best track (and second single) â€œThe Evil Has Landed,â€ is the only song that actually features the all-out one-chord guitar attack we love from QOTSA. And, as the albumâ€™s penultimate track, it comes as a prodigal return. Closer â€œVillains of Circumstance,â€ a song thatâ€™s existed in the QOTSA canon for at least a few years now, lets some of Hommeâ€™s deeply underrated vocals shine (although the song does die out on a disappointing finale).

Unfortunately, there is some dead weight. QOTSA have never really been a band to attempt slow songs, and on â€œVillainsâ€ we find out why. â€œFortressâ€ starts with promise but hits a real sour tone when the pace never picks up. Also, â€œUn-Reborn Againâ€ is a track that starts out as a ton of fun, but well overstays its welcome. 6:41 isnâ€™t exactly a foreign length for a QOTSA song, but at the four-minute mark I was already finding myself waiting for the end. Even if the new, upbeat turn is refreshing, there is a lack of the guitar bashing we expect. â€œVillainsâ€ feels like a balanced effort that doesnâ€™t quite make the correct scale at times.

All of that said and done, Mark Ronson producing a Queens of the Stone Age release is an equally wild and understandable effort, and itâ€™s pretty full of jams. This album might not have any of the best QOTSA songs â€“ and they exist on every album â€“ but it is mostly consistent throughout and certainly stands out as their most unique effort so far. The band might not ever put out another â€œSongs For the Deaf,â€ but this content is more than acceptable. Just donâ€™t take so long next time.

-By Andrew McNally

Grade: C+

Key Tracks: â€œEverything Now,â€ â€œCreature Comfortâ€

I recently read an article that called Arcade Fireâ€™s â€œRebellion (Lies)â€ one of the best rock songs of this century so far, and I donâ€™t doubt this for a second. Arcade Fireâ€™s perfect debut album â€œFuneralâ€ helped energize the brewing indie revolution by adding a full, baroque sound. While bands like Interpol and the Yeah Yeah Yeahs beat them by a few years, they were championing a much more straightforward, guitar-driven approach. Unfortunately, that revolution came to a halt, and many of the genreâ€™s best broke up or shouldâ€™ve broken up. Arcade Fire were an exception until this point, finding ways to combine some current form of music zeitgeist with the general bleakness and storytelling of their indie background.

Unfortunately for Arcade Fire, theyâ€™ve always been a conceptual band, and each of their albums exists (very intentionally) in different spaces. Their first album is a bleak baroque tale of a town where only kids survive a snowfall so bad that it covers houses. â€œNeon Bibleâ€ is a Springsteen-tinged ode to Americaâ€™s Bible belt. â€œReflektorâ€ is a sad dance party, accentuated by James Murphy and David Bowie (!). None of these are concept albums â€“ just albums centered a relative narrative idea. Their idea for â€œEverything Nowâ€ (a tongue-in-cheek title, given the bandâ€™s patience in between releases), is one of a band that has hit a huge stature and is afraid of disappointing. This isnâ€™t the first time a band has done this â€“ Queens of the Stone Age attempted a similar idea on their last album â€œâ€¦Like Clockwork.â€ Foxygen did a similar thing on â€œStar Power.â€ Itâ€™s just that this ideaâ€¦.isnâ€™t a very good one. There are many different routes that the band could take, from deep introspection on how fame changed their personal lives, or an intentionally messy album that doesnâ€™t do any narrative justice. But they chose the option of being the band that disappoints with a boring album.

The worst part about this is that it doesnâ€™t necessarily feel like a conscious change. â€œEverything Now,â€ produced partially by Daft Punkâ€™s Thomas Bangalter (along others), feels like a natural progression to â€œReflektor.â€ The album feels like the characters on that album have grown up more and made peace with their surroundings. So while the music of this album might feel intentionally lackadaisical, some of the other elements feel unintentionally so. Front and center is Win Butlerâ€™s vocals. The man has historically gelled into whatever the song needs. As I write this, â€œModern Manâ€ is playing. Butlerâ€™s voice in this is timid and reserved, especially compared to the high-volume of â€œRebellion (Lies)â€ or the shout-y section of â€œNeighborhood #3 (Power Out).â€ On this album, though, Butler mostly meanders through his lyrics like he doesnâ€™t even care that he wrote them.

And maybe he doesnâ€™t â€“ because on the whole the lyrics are pretty terrible. They sing repeatedly about the somewhat vague concepts of â€˜infinite contentâ€™ and â€˜everything nowâ€™ (which make up 5 of the 13 track titles), loose terms about the availability of music on the internet. Lyrically, the band is trying to hold themselves to an impossibly high standard, knowing all of their competition in the world. Theyâ€™re throwing in a satirical white flag. So to hear such limp lyrics throughout is disappointing in both concept and reality. â€œInfinite Contentâ€ and â€œInfinite_Contentâ€ share the same lyrics, and they shouldnâ€™t, because theyâ€™re all centered on a corny line. â€œChemistry,â€ though one of the stronger tracks, also has corny as hell lyrics. So does â€œSigns of Life,â€ a song where Butler at one point literally raps the days of the week (yikes!).

This album is by no means a complete waste. The title track is dance-pop gold (though, as with â€œReflektor,â€ they make the mistake of putting the best track early and releasing it as the first single). â€œPut Your Money On Meâ€ takes a long time to build, but once it does it hits a climax more complex than the other tracks. RÃ©gine Chassagne has her moment on â€œCreature Comfort,â€ easily out-singing her husband. â€œChemistry,â€ too, is pleasant â€“ though it would be more pleasant if it was a different artist. There are undercurrents of new wave on this album, especially on â€œChemistryâ€ and â€œSigns of Life.â€ Butlerâ€™s rapping on the latter is reminiscent of Deborah Harryâ€™s â€˜rapâ€™ verse on â€œRapture,â€ although Harryâ€™s was much more of a â€˜time and placeâ€™ thing. The title track, as dance-pop as it is, also feels a little ripped from â€™78.

But elsewhere, the album is just a big dud. Chassagneâ€™s spotlight moment on this album comes on â€œElectric Blue,â€ a song so painfully dull that it took me two tries to listen to. â€œWe Donâ€™t Deserve Loveâ€ sets itself as the standout, and while it does have some of the albumâ€™s better lyrics, itâ€™s a long dud that never does anything to grab the listener. Some of the albumâ€™s best points come in the intro/outro/interludes, which is telling. The punk blast that is â€œInfinite Contentâ€ is on par with their chaotic early days, but itâ€™s only a fleeting memory, one that gets taken over by an immediate country-reworking of the same song.

Itâ€™s also telling that I canâ€™t pick a pinpoint critique to go on about. Arcade Fire are one of my favorite bands (I mean this), but this album is just a burned-out fuse top to bottom. There is no energy, corny lyrics, and tepid vocals. Nothing that Arcade Fire is known for is done on display here, itâ€™s just a dull dance-pop album start to finish. The band â€“ which still has more members than most bands â€“ rarely alters between a few chords throughout the album. There just doesnâ€™t seem to be anything inspired at all here, and if itâ€™s all part of the image of the album, then it is not successful. Either way, itâ€™s a misfire. This album wonâ€™t damage the love that I have for the band, because their music has helped me in ways that I can never explain. But itâ€™s also completely forgettable from start to finish. The fact that the last track resets back into the first one is a kind of ironic poison, that is has to live in its own prison of mediocrity. This isnâ€™t a water putting out the Arcade Fire, but it is a rekindling. This album will never stand up to the ones that came before it; to those who still derive a lot of pleasure from it, the more power to you. Iâ€™m seeing them in September and I hope these tracks translate better live. But for now, weâ€™re left with a big pile of nothing.

-By Andrew McNally

Grade: A-

Key Tracks: â€œGreen Light,â€ â€œHard Feelings/Loveless,â€ â€œPerfect Placesâ€

The first album from New Zealand singer Lorde, 2014â€™s wonderful instant classic â€œPure Heroine,â€ was a bit of an anomaly. Lordeâ€™s lyrics shadowed the fact that she was literally a teenager â€“ they coupled the life of suburbia with the dreams of luxuries she heard about in Drake and Kanye songs. But musically, the album couldnâ€™t have been further from what a bored teenaged pop singer usually creates. The album was a quiet blast of minimalism, with short, mild songs more in the realm of The xx than anything else. It was a refreshing turn for a young singer. But it also left people wondering whether her follow-up would try to replicate the style, or whether Lorde would grow her music.

Unsurprisingly, Lorde grew. The albumâ€™s opening track and lead single, â€œGreen Light,â€ is a tongue-in-cheek look at this. The opening line, â€œI do my make-up in somebody elseâ€™s car,â€ could easily come out of a Lorde parody song, and is sung over faint piano. But within a minute the song does literally grow into a big, extremely danceable pop song. This album, in certain ways, could not sound more different than â€œHeroine.â€ While Lorde sounded comfortable in that albumâ€™s small sound, here she often sounds like sheâ€™s trying to free herself from a restraint (often successfully). â€œGreen Lightâ€ lacks a breakdown because Lorde sings over it at the same volume she was already going at. On this album she has both more range and more bite. On â€œWriter in the Darkâ€ she coolly sings â€œI love you till my breathing stops / I love you till you call the cops on meâ€ over two menacingly out-of-tune piano notes. On â€œThe Louvre,â€ she surrounds herself with the most orchestral music sheâ€™s made, which makes the painful quietness of immediate follow-up â€œLiabilityâ€ all the more real.

But the best example of this newfound, punching-up attitude is found on the first half of â€œHard Feelings/Loveless.â€ The â€œHard Feelingsâ€ portion of the song expands into industrial territory â€“ yes, industrial territory. Lordeâ€™s vocals completely disappear for a noisy interlude that wouldnâ€™t have felt out of place on â€œPretty Hate Machine.â€ Itâ€™s a real punch in the gut to hear it halfway into a pop album. Itâ€™s worth noting that Lorde worked with Jack Antonoff on this album, a man who isnâ€™t new to elevating female singers and pushing them in new directions. The album, as a whole, is far more musical than before. There are multiple songs with instrumental fade-outs and moments where Lorde gives way to the music behind her. Sheâ€™s not hidden, though â€“ she still dominates every song in her own ways.

â€œMelodramaâ€ might be the most appropriately-titled album of the year. While it is taken from a song, the whole album has an umbrella of melodrama to it. Lorde, now 20, seems stuck in the same lyrical ennui that birthed her first album. But here she is more direct while also more unhinged. Gone are the references to diamonds and luxury, the metaphors and vocal inspirations taken from other genres (except the way Lorde sings the chorus in the excellent â€œThe Louvreâ€) Sheâ€™s bored in relationships, counting the days until it ends. Sheâ€™s alone in clubs, sometimes by choice and sometimes not. â€œMelodrama,â€ even more than â€œHeroine,â€ shows the personal troubles and misunderstood complexity of being a young woman. And although she may be native to New Zealand, the general â€˜stuckâ€™ feeling throughout wouldnâ€™t sound out of place coming from a Midwestern act. Many of the albumâ€™s songs could easily be translated into the music of a young but learned country singer.

Lordeâ€™s growth as a singer is completely natural on this album, and it isnâ€™t even necessarily a growth that would usually be called â€œmaturity.â€ Her image was so well solidified on â€œHeroineâ€ and it came off so earnestly that this album feels more like a reaction, rather than a separate entity. And on a bigger and simpler note, it also proves that Lorde isnâ€™t going to be a one-off (not that we were particularly worried). â€œMelodramaâ€ is a surprisingly well-rounded package, one that highlights and intensifies the emotions she had already conquered, while also pushing her volume and ambition levels far past what listeners were used to. A week removed from Katy Perryâ€™s disastrous push into new ground, we get the album we might deserve â€“ a pop singer pushing herself to the edge of her capabilities without intentionally going overboard.

-By Andrew McNally

Grade: B+

Key Tracks: â€œAlready Naked,â€ â€œFragmentsâ€

Certain bands hit a legendary status where they can have others write music for them. We saw it last with the proto-new Monkees album that had contributions from both Harry Nilsson and Rivers Cuomo. Well, Blondie have hit that status. Although they donâ€™t have the amount of material or the longevity (remember their 15 year break), Blondie shook music so much that theyâ€™re able to have outside help.

But before we discuss the non-Blondie elements, we should discuss the band itself. This album has a renewed energy and a consistent groove to it, and itâ€™s safe to say it rivals that of their original late â€™70â€™s run. The band is locked in on every song. And, as with any great Blondie album, thereâ€™s a respectable mix of new wave, ballads, disco and punk. The album is bookended with two great rock songs, â€œDoom or Destinyâ€ and â€œFragments,â€ the latter sporting an unexpected and effective tempo change. â€œLong Timeâ€ balances out a pleasantly bouncy beat with a delicate bridge. â€œWhen I Gave Up On Youâ€ is a great ballad, and one that brings the albumâ€™s momentum down a bit. And although â€œMy Monsterâ€ might not be the best track, the blending of guitar and synth over unexpectedly monotone vocals makes it arguably the most interesting. Debbie Harry hasnâ€™t missed a beat â€“ her voice dominates the album. It hasnâ€™t changed in the slightest â€“ modest, but dominating. Only in â€œAlready Nakedâ€ does it feel like the band relies on her, though, which is good. In the albumâ€™s other ten tracks, her voice patiently but strongly leads the band.

After a fairly mediocre outing where the band took on a more electronic approach, Blondie decided to tag in to some other writers for this album. This isnâ€™t to say theyâ€™ve given up â€“ merely that they felt fans would rather appreciate great songs written by other people to decent songs written by them. And the person who shows up the most in the songwriting credits is indeed Debbie Harry. The classic duo of Harry and guitarist Chris Stein penned two tracks on this album: opener â€œDoom or Destinyâ€ and â€œLove Level.â€ Harry also has a credit alongside Blood Orange on â€œLong Time.â€ Keyboardist Matt Katz-Bohen and his wife Laurel are credited on two songs as well. Other songwriters that aided include Dave Sitek from TV on the Radio, Charli XCX, The Gregory Brothers, and Adam Johnston, a writer for YourMovieSucks.org. Almost ironically, the albumâ€™s weakest track â€œBest Day Ever,â€ was written by Sia and Nick Valensi of the Strokes.

Despite the credits, the album is somewhat sparse on actual guest appearances. Joan Jett (who is not credited as a songwriter) appears on opener â€œDoom or Destiny.â€ Johnny Marr, Charli XCX, the Gregory Brothers and Adam Johnston appear on the songs that they co-wrote. The sole other appearance is that of John Roberts. Readers may know Roberts as the voice of Linda Belcher on the unbelievably great FOX animated show â€œBobâ€™s Burgers.â€ I do not know the circumstances that led him to appearing on a Blondie record. The track he shows up on, â€œLove Level,â€ is the only one that approaches hip-hop in any way. Admittedly, itâ€™s pretty jarring, because itâ€™s not only the only pseudo-rap heard on the album, itâ€™s also the only prominent male voice. As a song, it works, but in the context of the album, itâ€™s a little much of a curveball.

At the end of the day, this is just a very good Blondie album. For a band that spent their heyday trying everything, they sound comfortable going back to some basics. They nail both the jams and the ballads, and they sound great as a collective. The energy is there, the diversity is there, and Debbie Harryâ€™s vocals are there, so there is reason to rejoice. Forty-three years and eleven albums in, Blondie still sound young and fresh. And really, isnâ€™t that what Blondie is supposed to be?

-By Andrew McNally

Grade: B-

You might be reading articles about people in media and come across the concept of an artist making something â€œfor themselves.â€ I think itâ€™s a great idea â€“ as a singer/director/painter/composer/what have you, someone is fed up with reviews, praise and criticism that they make a piece of art that they know theyâ€™ll enjoy. Weâ€™ve seen it in music â€“ look at Bob Dylanâ€™s recent output. Heâ€™s been doing it for practically his whole career, itâ€™s just that people latched on to most of it. We saw it in film version earlier this year, when my favorite filmmakers Joel and Ethan Coen put out a movie called â€œHail, Caesarâ€ that was so into their own irrelevant personal politics that it was borderline unwatchable to anyone who didnâ€™t share their name(s). This is what Justin Vernonâ€™s new album sounds like. Vernon, the frontman and ship-commander of Bon Iver, has never been shy to air his grievances on tape. Itâ€™s just here, he does it in a way that alters between being heartbreakingly original and just painfully pretentious.

Vernon is a man who has always dipped his feet into many different pools. It would be easy to say that his big break came when Bon Iver picked up two huge Grammys in 2012 â€“ Best Alternative Album, beating Radiohead and Death Cab For Cutie, and Best New Artist, beating â€“ wait for this â€“ The Band Perry, J. Cole, Skrillex, and Nicki Minaj. But in that same year, Justin Vernon was featured on an album, maybe you know it, Kanye Westâ€™s â€œMy Beautiful Dark Twisted Fantasy.â€ Although he swept up the Grammyâ€™s in his own indie-folk persona, he snuck in a bunch of nominations via Kanye, a fan who invited him in the studio. I would argue that â€œMonster,â€ in which Vernon is 1/5 of musicians present, is one of this centuryâ€™s best hip-hop songs, and it introduced a whole different audience to his music.

I mention all of this not to be condescending or anything; I mention it because it has become clear that a possibly unintentional association to the hip-hop community has definitely changed Vernonâ€™s music. The first two Bon Iver albums â€“ which came out in 2008 and 2011, respectively, capitalized on the indie-folk movement that was big at the time. Theyâ€™re gems, throughout. Iâ€™ll admit that Iâ€™ve never felt the connection to them that a lot of people have, but they are gems. Four years later, after a self-imposed hiatus, Vernonâ€™s Bon Iver still reflects the music movements of today. But it doesnâ€™t capture the current eclectic zeitgeist as well. In an age where A$ap Rocky records with Florence Welch, David Bowie writes an album inspired by Kendrick Lamar, and Bruce Springsteen praises Kanye, there is an insane amount of cross-blending going on.

At times, Bon Iverâ€™s album hits emotional highs where his new concoction of hip-hop induced freakfolk strikes an emotional cord that somehow has not been hit yet. Opening track â€œ22 (OVER SâˆâˆN)â€ is a brutally honest way to open an album, with Vernon seemingly pondering his own existence, singing â€œIt might be over soon.â€ The song falls to a saxophone bit that plays over a particularly grating chant. One of the albumâ€™s best tracks is â€œ33â€GODâ€,â€ which ironically works because of its clarity. The song is the clearest song on the album â€“ the song that sounds the most like traditional Bon Iver. In a weird way, itâ€™s refreshing.

Vernonâ€™s lyrics throughout the album are his strongest suit. His words are emotionally distant and discontent â€“ the words of a man who never planned on being famous and showing up on Kanye albums. The main problem is, sometimes those lyrics are simply indecipherable. Parts of this album beg the question often posed to bands like Lightning Bolt or Deafheaven â€“ does renegading your lyrics behind a curtain of indecipherability render them pointless?

The album, when not highlighting a poignant, dissonant emotional feel, gives into its worst indulgences. Vernon has recorded with and under a number of bands and aliases, so itâ€™s tough not to wonder why he felt the Bon Iver moniker was the right one for this album. Itâ€™s wildly different, to a point where it feels like Vernon flaunting his own split in the biggest avenue he can find, and that avenue just happens to be Bon Iver. The album has great tracks â€“ but ones like the utterly dull â€œ29 #Stafford APTSâ€ or the annoyingly grating, a capella â€œ715 â€“ CRÎ£Î£KSâ€ make you wonder why this album has to exist in the first place. Thereâ€™s little middle ground here â€“ thereâ€™s either tracks that capture beauty amidst roughness, or just the roughness. On both go-arounds I made of this album, I had to restart â€œ8 (circle)â€ because both times I completely forgot I was listening to music. Vernon retreats into himself on this album â€“ and when he has an emotional center to bounce off, then heâ€™s written some of the best songs of his career. But at other times, heâ€™s become so self-indulgent that it doesnâ€™t even feel like there should be another listener besides him.

The song titles donâ€™t help his case. Donâ€™t trust every review that praises the mystical song titles â€“ sure, each one has a number. Do we know what it means? Not really. Does it seem to matter? Not really. I donâ€™t know how many people were truly excited to see the torch that Devendra Banhart abandoned be picked up, but this isnâ€™t really the way to do it. Calling a song something like â€œ____45_____â€ doesnâ€™t intrinsically add anything of value, it just makes it look different. And in this case, that different is goofy, not inspirational. Vernon treats this album like he is the grandmaster of freakfolk, but he isnâ€™t, not by decades. Maybe he was influenced by Kanye, maybe these tracks came out of his own frutration and Iâ€™m just not accepting them correctly. But â€œ22, A Millionâ€ just doesnâ€™t feel like the revolutionary piece of art that the band so seems to think it is. It definitely takes multiple listens, and it is never what you expect. At times, it is nothing but sheer greatness. But it is also such a mess of pretentious experimental nonsense that it never answers the basic question of why it needs to exist in the first place. Some people will love it; some really wonâ€™t. Maybe Justin Vernon made this album for himself, or maybe he made it for those fans. Either way, â€œ22, A Millionâ€ never rises above being a reminder of the better freak-folk acts of the past.

-By Andrew McNally

Grade: A-

Key Tracks: â€œTiny,â€ â€œI Walk For Milesâ€

Itâ€™s taken a while, but it seems like Dinosaur Jr. are finally getting their due praise. On their new album, their 11th and their 7th with the original line-up, the Massachusetts rockers double down on what made them so influential in the first place. Yes, theyâ€™re the band that did â€œFeel the Painâ€ in 1994, but they still rock harder than most young bands do nowadays.

The bandâ€™s 2005 reunion was unexpected, to the point where people mentioned them in the same breath of the Smiths in bands that would never reunite. Since then, the band â€“ in its original three-piece lineup â€“ has maintained a consistency in songwriting, and has delivered a number of albums as intense and interesting as those released in the late 80â€™s. Although their first post-reunion album, â€œBeyondâ€ set a high watermark, the albums theyâ€™ve released since â€“ including â€œGive a Glimpse of What Yer Not,â€ have been nothing other than advertised â€“ 40-odd minutes of great rock jams and crazy guitar solos.

Dinosaur Jr. is basically a template by this point. The best radio rock is. Queens of the Stone Age, Foo Fighters â€“ bands that have a â€œsoundâ€ and make songs that are interchangeable among decades, but still feel the urge to include some little unique tick in every track they can. And, truthfully, those bands might not have existed without Dinosaur Jr. They were deeply influential to grunge, but even more so to bands like Foo Fighters, who dominate the alt-rock hybrid radio stations today. Dinosaur Jr. are one of a few bands alongside the likes of Pixies, Mudhoney, Meat Puppets and Green River, among others, who influenced the grunge movement and had their own twilight after the fact. Well, Dinosaur Jr. are still going strong (as are Pixies, Mudhoney and Meat Puppets), and it would be easy to confuse â€œGlimpseâ€ as an album that came in â€™88.

The trio wastes no time getting to the point on the album â€“ the opening and best track, â€œGoin Down,â€ starts with a quick second of amp feedback before getting right into one of the simplest and best riffs J. Mascis has written in years. The song transitions nicely into â€œTiny,â€ by all means a catchy and great rock song that ends in a mess of feedback. The album gets somewhat inconsistent from there, but even at itâ€™s dullest itâ€™s still engaging. Tracks like â€œGood to Knowâ€ and â€œLost All Dayâ€ arenâ€™t particularly memorable, but still stand as great, fuzzy jams. And on the flipside, â€œI Walk For Milesâ€ and â€œKnocked Aroundâ€ both have tempo and mood changes that make them among some of the most memorable songs the band has ever recorded.

The lyrics to Dinosaur Jr. songs have never been typically interesting, and itâ€™s fair to say that continues here. â€œI Walk For Milesâ€ is also a lyrical highlight, with an ode to a friendship or relationship of some kind falling by the wayside. But even when the lyrics arenâ€™t interesting, J. Mascisâ€™s vocals continue to be. The chorus to opener â€œGoin Downâ€ is sung straight even when the rhythm doesnâ€™t fit with it. His vocals sound more strained than ever on â€œTiny,â€ and forlorn on â€œI Walk For Miles.â€ Still, having Lou Barlow pop up twice on vocals â€“ on tracks 5 and 11 â€“ is a welcome relief, as Mascisâ€™s voice can prove decisive over 5 or 6 songs.

Also, the guitar playing. Oh man. Itâ€™s no secret â€“ thatâ€™s what makes Dinosaur Jr. great. Simple rhythms and fuzzy 70â€™s throwback melodies get wrecked by J. Mascis, who solos on what I believe is 10 out of the albumâ€™s 11 tracks. On Rolling Stoneâ€™s 2011 re-ranking of the 100 Greatest Guitarists, Mascis jumped in to the 88th spot, beating the likes of Carl Perkins, Springsteen, Thurston Moore and my favorite guitarist, Tom Verlaine. Itâ€™s noteworthy that in lieu of a third single, Dinosaur Jr. just put all of the guitar solos as one track online to stream in advance of the album. One great thing about Dinosaur Jr. is knowing that even if itâ€™s one of the less interesting tracks, thereâ€™s still a killer solo coming up.

This might not go down as a classic Dinosaur Jr. album. But it is great, nearly every song is worthwhile. It serves as a testament to the bands duration, their influence, and their energy, that theyâ€™ve kept this act up for so many years now. While they might not be the most popular rock bands, theyâ€™re one of the most influential. Buy it, stream it, do whatever pleases you: just please listen to Dinosaur Jr.

-By Andrew McNally
